document.masterDocTitle: The taxonomy of the American Ariadna Audouin (Araneae: Synspermiata: Segestriidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ariadna boliviana Simon, 1907 : 262
(♀ lectotype and ♂ lectoparatype from Espíritu Santo, [16°55'S; 67°48'W], BoliVia, Garlepp leg., deposited in MNHNP-AR 14382 and 14383, respectively, designated by Beatty (1970) , examined).— Petrunkevitch (1911: 130) .— Beatty (1970: 477, figs 4, 6, 14, 51‒52, 54‒55) .— World Spider Catalog (2018) .

Ariadna dubia Mello-Leitão, 1917 : 82
(♀ holotype from Pinheiro (actually Piraí, Pinheiral [22°30'46"S, 44°00'03"W], Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, E. Brito leg., should be deposited in MNRJ 1452, lost).—
Beatty (1970: 483, as nomem dubium )
.—
Moreira et al. (2010
: 61).—
NEW SYNONYMY
.

Synonymy. Mello-Leitão (1917) described
A. dubia
based in a dried and pinned specimen, with a deformed and seared abdomen. Beatty (1970) , due to the unavailability of the holotype and the poor description of Mello-Leitão, treated it as nomem dubium . There are two species registered to the type-locality of
A. dubia
:
Ariadna boliviana Simon, 1907
and
Ariadna obscura ( Blackwall, 1858 )
. According to the macrosetae pattern presented by Mello-Leitão (1917) in
A. dubia
's original description, the tibiae I‒II presents 2-2-2-2 pattern (vp1-0-1-0-1-0-1, vr1-0-1-0-1-0-1) and metatarsi I and II with seven pairs of macrosetae. This macrosetae pattern is consistent with the one from
A. boliviana
, and differs from
A. obscura
. Based in the characters presented by Mello-Leitão (1917) ,
A. dubia
is considered junior-synonymy of
A. boliviana
.

Additional material examined: SURINAME :

Diagnosis.
Ariadna boliviana
is similar to
A. isthmica
,
A. ipojuca
n. sp.
and
A. gaucha
n. sp.
due to the morphology of male palp ( Figs 37A‒B , 44A‒B , 58G‒H , 61A‒B ), metatarsi IV ( Figs 36F , 43F , 58F , 60F ), and leg macrosetae pattern of females, but differ by the presence of males with sinuous metatarsi I, with a marked bend in the proximal region ( Fig. 36C‒E ); females differ from these species, except
A. gaucha
n. sp.
, by the presence of a ventral lobe longer than the dorsal one; it differs from
A. gaucha
n. sp.
by the less sinuous ventral lobe ( Figs 10A‒C , 37C‒D ).

Variation. Male (n=10): Total length 5.2‒8.64; carapace 2.8‒4.12 long, 1.96‒2.8 wide; femur I 2.96‒3.96. Female (n=10): total length 8.4‒12.4; carapace 4.12‒5.76 long, 2.6‒3.8 wide; femur I 2.84‒4.52.

Distribution. Suriname , Bolivia ,
Paraguay
and almost entire Brazilian territory ( Fig. 71 ).
